TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit StatusBar extends System.Windows.Forms.Control

Docs.summary: Represents a Windows status bar control. Although replaces and adds functionality to the StatusBar control of previous versions, StatusBar is retained for both backward compatibility and future use if you choose.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Typically, a StatusBar control consists of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects, each of which displays text and/or an icon. You can also provide owner-drawn panels to provide custom panels such as a progress bar or a series of images that displays the state of your application. A StatusBar control typically displays information about an object being viewed on a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, the object's components, or contextual information that relates to that object's operation within your application.
The StatusBar control provides properties that enable you to customize the appearance of the control. If the StatusBar is displayed on a form that can be resized, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.SizingGrip%2A> property to display a sizing grip in the lower-right corner of the form to indicate to users that the form can be resized. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.ShowPanels%2A> property enables you to display panels within your StatusBar or to display only the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Text%2A> property of the control.
The default StatusBar has no panels. To add panels to a StatusBar you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> class that is accessible through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.Panels%2A> property of the control. You can also use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> object provided through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.Panels%2A> property to remove panels from the control and access a specific <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> to manipulate the panel.
If you want to determine when a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> object within a StatusBar control is clicked, you can create an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.PanelClick> event. To perform owner-draw operations on a panel, you can create an event handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.DrawItem> event. The event data passed to the event handler provides information on the panel to draw and a <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to use to perform drawing tasks.
When you create an instance of StatusBar, the read/write properties are set to initial values. For a list of these values, see the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
## Examples The following code example creates a StatusBar control on a form and adds two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects. One of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects, named `panel1`, displays status text for an application. The second <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel>, named `panel2`, displays the current date and uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.ToolTipText%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> class to display the current time. The example uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.ShowPanels%2A> property to ensure that the panels are displayed instead of a standard panel, and it uses and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.Panels%2A> property to access the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> to add the panels to the StatusBar. The example also uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.AutoSize%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.BorderStyle%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.ToolTipText%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Text%2A> properties to initialize the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects. This example requires that the method defined in the example is defined and called from the constructor of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.windows.forms.s_13_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.windows.forms.s_13_1.cs)] [!code-vb[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.windows.forms.s_13_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The default <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> has no panels.
When you create an instance of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar>, the following read/write properties are set to initial values.
|Property|Initial value| |--------------|-------------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dock%2A>|<xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle>| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.ShowPanels%2A>|`false`| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.SizingGrip%2A>|`true`|
You can change the value for any of these properties through a separate call to the property.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to construct a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> and use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.SizingGrip%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Alignment%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Width%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.AutoSize%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.BorderStyle%2A?displayProperty=fullName> members and how to handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.PanelClick> event.
To run the example, paste the following code in a form. Call the `InitializeStatusBarPanels` method in the form's constructor or `Load` method.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.windows.forms.s_0_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.windows.forms.s_0_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.windows.forms.s_0_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

Docs.param: to release both managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
Docs.summary: Disposes of the resources (other than memory) used by the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method is called by the public `Dispose` method and the <xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> method. `Dispose` invokes the protected `Dispose(Boolean)` method with the `disposing` parameter set to `true`. <xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> invokes `Dispose` with `disposing` set to `false`.
When the `disposing` parameter is `true`, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> references. This method invokes the `Dispose` method of each referenced object.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Setting this property has no effect on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control, therefore it is not shown in the designer or by IntelliSense.

Docs.summary: Occurs when a visual aspect of an owner-drawn status bar control changes.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this event to perform drawing operations in an owner-drawn <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control. For example, if you display an owner-drawn <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> that displays a progress bar, you can use this event to perform the drawing of the progress bar on the panel. The data provided to the event through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarDrawItemEventArgs> object passed as a parameter to the event handler enables you to determine the panel that needs to be drawn and the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> to use to draw to the panel. This event is only raised when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Style%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelStyle>.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create an owner-drawn <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> that displays a custom background and the current date. This example requires that you have connected the DrawItem event of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control to the event handler defined in the example.
[!code-cs[StatusBar.DrawItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e-system.windows.forms.s_5_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[StatusBar.DrawItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/e-system.windows.forms.s_5_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[StatusBar.DrawItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e-system.windows.forms.s_5_1.vb)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnDrawItem method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to create an owner-drawn <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> that displays a custom background and the current date. This example requires that you have connected the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.DrawItem> event of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control to the event handler defined in the example.
[!code-cs[StatusBar.DrawItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/1877c4fe-ba5c-4870-adb5-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[StatusBar.DrawItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/1877c4fe-ba5c-4870-adb5-_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[StatusBar.DrawItem#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/1877c4fe-ba5c-4870-adb5-_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Occurs when the control is redrawn.
Occurs when a object on a control is clicked.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this event to perform tasks when a panel within a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control is clicked. The data provided to the event through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelClickEventArgs> passed as a parameter to the event handler enables you to determine the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> that was clicked by the user in order to perform tasks on the selected panel.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.SizingGrip%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Alignment%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Width%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.AutoSize%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.BorderStyle%2A?displayProperty=fullName> members and how to handle the PanelClick event.
To run the example, paste the following code in a form. Call the `InitializeStatusBarPanels` method in the form's constructor or `Load` method.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/e-system.windows.forms.s_2_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/e-system.windows.forms.s_2_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/e-system.windows.forms.s_2_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Gets the collection of panels contained within the control.
Docs.value: A <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> containing the objects of the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control can display a number of panels to provide information to the user of your application. For example, a panel could display the current time or the progress of a file download. Each panel displayed by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control is an instance of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> class. The Panels property enables you to obtain a reference to the collection of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects that are currently stored in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control. With this reference, you can add panels, remove panels, access a specific panel within the collection, and obtain a count of the panels in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control. For more information on the tasks that can be performed with the panel collection, see the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> class reference topics.
## Examples The following code example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control on a form and adds two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects. One of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects, named `panel1`, displays status text for an application. The second <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> object, named `panel2`, displays the current date and uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.ToolTipText%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> class to display the current time. The example uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.ShowPanels%2A> property to ensure that the panels are displayed instead of a standard panel, and it uses and the Panels property to access the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> to add the panels to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar>. The example also uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.AutoSize%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.BorderStyle%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.ToolTipText%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Text%2A> properties to initialize the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects. This example requires that the method defined in the example is defined and called from the constructor of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.s_158_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.s_158_1.cs)] [!code-vb[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.s_158_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether any panels that have been added to the control are displayed.
Docs.value: if panels are displayed; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control displays the value of its <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Text%2A> property without any panels. When `ShowPanels` is set to `true`, any <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects specified in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control are displayed. No panels are initially created when you create an instance of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> class. You can add panels to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control by using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> class. This collection class can be accessed through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.Panels%2A> property of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar>.
## Examples The following code example creates a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control on a form and adds two <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects. One of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects, named `panel1`, displays status text for an application. The second <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel>, named `panel2`, displays the current date and uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.ToolTipText%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> class to display the current time. The example uses the ShowPanels property to ensure that the panels are displayed instead of a standard panel, and it uses and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.Panels%2A> property to access the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection.Add%2A> method of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.StatusBarPanelCollection> to add the panels to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar>. The example also uses the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.AutoSize%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.BorderStyle%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.ToolTipText%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Text%2A> properties to initialize the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel> objects. This example requires that the method defined in the example is defined and called from the constructor of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
[!code-cpp[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.s_105_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.s_105_1.cs)] [!code-vb[StatusBar and StatusBarPanel Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.s_105_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a sizing grip is displayed in the lower-right corner of the control.
Docs.value: if a sizing grip is displayed; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property to display a sizing grip to provide an indication to the user when a form is resizable. If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.FormBorderStyle%2A> property of your <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> is set to a border style that is not resizable, such as<xref:System.Windows.Forms.FormBorderStyle> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.FormBorderStyle>, you should set the SizingGrip property to `false` to prevent the user from thinking that the form can be resized.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the SizingGrip, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Alignment%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.Width%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.AutoSize%2A?displayProperty=fullName>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanel.BorderStyle%2A?displayProperty=fullName> members and how to handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar.PanelClick> event.
To run the example, paste the following code in a form. Call the `InitializeStatusBarPanels` method in the form's constructor or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Load> event handler.
[!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.s_161_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.s_161_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarPanelExample#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.s_161_1.cpp)]

Docs.value: if the tab key moves focus to the ; otherwise . The default is .

MemberSignature.Value: public override string Text { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text associated with the control.
Docs.value: The text associated with the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property represents the text displayed by the control.
> [!CAUTION] > The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control displays only the first 127 characters of a string.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the Text property. To run the example, paste the following code in a form. Call the `InitializeSimpleStatusBar` method in the form's constructor or `Load` method.
[!code-cpp[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarDrawItemEventHandler#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.windows.forms.s_90_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarDrawItemEventHandler#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.windows.forms.s_90_1.cs)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.StatusBarDrawItemEventHandler#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.windows.forms.s_90_1.vb)]

Docs.summary: Processes Windows messages.
